DataElement.preferredName: International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification Histopathologic Diagnostic Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the component of the International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification (INPC) for histopathologic diagnostic category (reflects tumor and stromal content).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Neuroblastoma International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification Histology
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Neuroblastoma is a specific type of neuroblastic tumor which is characterized by the presense of neuroblastic cells forming groups or nests separated by delicate stromal septa without prominent Schwannian stroma. (Adapted from WHO.)_A classification system established by adopting the original system proposed by Shimada with subsequent revisions. The INPC distinguishes favorable and unfavorable histology groups._The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Neuroblastoma is a specific type of neuroblastic tumor which is characterized by the presense of neuroblastic cells forming groups or nests separated by delicate stromal septa without prominent Schwannian stroma. (Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A malignant neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, the absence of ganglion cells, and the absence of a prominent Schwannian stroma formation.

Property.preferredDefinition: A classification system established by adopting the original system proposed by Shimada with subsequent revisions. The INPC distinguishes favorable and unfavorable histology groups.:The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: A classification system established by adopting the original system proposed by Shimada with subsequent revisions. The INPC distinguishes favorable and unfavorable histology groups.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Reviewed and approved for release by T.Davidsen. mc 7/24/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification Histopathologic Diagnostic Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Neuroblastoma is a specific type of neuroblastic tumor which is characterized by the presense of neuroblastic cells forming groups or nests separated by delicate stromal septa without prominent Schwannian stroma. (Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A malignant neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, the absence of ganglion cells, and the absence of a prominent Schwannian stroma formation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ganglioneuroblastoma characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells in a Schwannian stroma, without the presence of hemorrhagic neuroblastic nodules.

Concepts.definition: A ganglioneuroblastoma characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells in a Schwannian stroma, without the presence of hemorrhagic neuroblastic nodules.

PermissibleValues.value: Ganglioneuroma, maturing subtype OR Ganglioneuroblastoma, well differentiated
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Ganglioneuroma (Schwannian stroma-dominant), maturing subtype OR Ganglioneuroblastoma, well differentiated (Schwannian stroma-rich)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Ganglioneuroma (Schwannian stroma-dominant), maturing subtype OR Ganglioneuroblastoma, well differentiated (Schwannian stroma-rich)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Ganglioneuroma (Schwannian stroma-dominant), maturing subtype OR Ganglioneuroblastoma, well differentiated (Schwannian stroma-rich)

A benign neuroblastic tumor of the sympathetic nervous system that occurs in childhood. Ganglioneuroma typically arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum. Histologic features include spindle cell proliferation (resembling a neurofibroma) and the presence of large ganglion cells. Common presenting features include a palpable abdominal mass, hepatomegaly, and a thoracic mass detected on routine chest X-ray.

Concepts.definition: A benign neuroblastic tumor of the sympathetic nervous system that occurs in childhood. Ganglioneuroma typically arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum. Histologic features include spindle cell proliferation (resembling a neurofibroma) and the presence of large ganglion cells. Common presenting features include a palpable abdominal mass, hepatomegaly, and a thoracic mass detected on routine chest X-ray.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.: A neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, ganglion cells, and a stroma with Schwannian differentiation constituting more than fifty-percent of the tumor volume.  There are two histologic subtypes identified: ganglioneuroblastoma, intermixed and ganglioneuroblastoma, nodular.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

A malignant neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, ganglion cells, and a stroma with Schwannian differentiation constituting more than fifty-percent of the tumor volume.  There are two histologic subtypes identified: ganglioneuroblastoma, intermixed and ganglioneuroblastoma, nodular.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ReferenceDocuments.description: If INPC diagnostic category is missing, then this is Shimada diagnostic category.
